repnme.cdata!:
Paraguay - Third Rural Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            rated as satisfactory. The main lessons learned from the
            project include: 1) Tariffs need to be set at sustainable
            levels. 2) Community participation in the various phases of
            the project is essential for the success and long-term
            sustainability of the project. 3) National Environmental
            Sanitation Services (SENASA) should make a sustained effort
            to collect the payments on the loans to the Juntas (a
            community organization). 4) SENASA should make increased use
            of alternative technologies and apply lower cost and
            appropriate solutions. 5) SENASA should strengthen its
            hygiene education activities to ensure that sanitation needs
            are adequately addressed. 6) SENASA should transform itself
            from an agency doing the works to one that facilitates the
            construction of systems. 7) SENASA should modernize its
            internal information systems. 8) Financing of water meters
            should be offered in the loans for Juntas (a community
            organization). 9) The provision of water and sanitation to
            the rural areas lends itself to the use of the Bank's
            "Adaptable Program Lending" instrument.

repnme.cdata!:
Paraguay - Third Rural Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Third Rural Water
            Supply and Sanitation project is to improve health
            conditions in the rural population.  The project will
            consist of: (a) building water supply systems in rural
            communities; (b) provision and improvement of on-site
            sanitation systems; (c) provision of water supply and
            sanitation systems to the dispersed rural population and
            indigenous settlements through low-cost appropriate
            technologies; (d) a technical assistance program consisting
            of consulting services of experts with international
            experience to assist and train personnel in how to carry out
            required special studies, project implementation techniques
            and development of an educational and promotional program to
            encourage community participation; and (e) institutional
            improvements for operations and maintenance including
            acquisition of well drilling equipment and spare parts for
            existing equipment, tools for regional repair shops,
            improvement of office facilities and equipment (computers,
            communications systems, etc.) vehicles for project
            implementation, and supervision.
